abstracts.cdata!:
The Integrated Watershed Development
            Project (IWDP) builds upon the success of an earlier
            Bank-assisted Project which concluded in 1999. IWDP aims to
            halt degradation in some 75 sub-watersheds of the Shivaliks,
            spanning some 200,000 hectares (ha), and to improve their
            potential for productivity. The sweep of IWDP covers
            improved cropping practices in the target watersheds, soil
            and water conservation, drainage line treatments through
            training and protection of water streams and livestock
            improvement. It also supports pasture development and the
            plantation of forests (on both private and community lands)
            for fuel wood and fodder, and experiments in innovative
            on-farm activities for soil and water conservation,
            including organic farming, composting and integrated pest
            management. The Project sought to encourage onsite water
            conservation on croplands and community lands in this region
            which gets an average annual rainfall of 800-1,200 mm.
